We're looking for a Testing Intern to join our dynamic QA team.What You'll Do:Assist in manual and automated testing of web and mobile applications.Identify, report, and track bugs.Collaborating with developers and QA leads to ensuring product quality.Learn testing tools and best practices.What Weâ€™re Looking For:Basic understanding of software testing concepts.Familiarity with tools like Selenium, Postman (a plus, not mandatory)Good communication and analytical skills.Enthusiasm to learn and grow in the QA domain.Requirements:Qualification: BE, MCA or equivalent.Experience: Freshers to 6 Months.Internship Duration: 6 MonthsLocation: MumbaiMode Of Work: Work From OfficeInterested?Send your resume toajay@synergyconnect.in.Feel free to DM me if you have any questions!Please like and share to help this reach the right candidates.", 'Why Charging Interns for Internship Opportunities is a Form of DeceptionI recently attended a meeting withUnified MentorPrivate Limited for their internship drive as mentioned, several of my questions were left unanswered and unresolved (as shown in the attached screenshot) despite the small group size at the end of meet.What I found particularly concerning was that Unified Mentor is offering internships at a price. These are not unpaid or paid internships, but rather, internships where students are required to pay for the opportunity to work.To make matters worse, they have different pricing tiers based on whether or not you receive an â€œinternship offerâ€:1 month: â‚¹399 (with an offer), â‚¹699 (without an offer)Pricing increases up to 6 months with similar plans (goes up to 4k+).While courses and training programs can involve fees, charging students for an internship is unethical. Internships are meant to provide valuable experience and skill development, not to financially exploit aspiring professionals.When I raised concerns about this practice, my questions were ignored and left unanswered.Internships should empower students with opportunities for growth, not create financial barriers. But I wonder what weâ€™ll do with that talent once they graduate. Deeptech research may consider itself safe, but after reading AI 2027 (https://ai-2027.com/) I wonder how long good â€œresearch appetiteâ€ will protect them.I donâ€™t have answers to the above grand challenges, but I do discuss how marketing can tackle this today with clients, as well asGrowthMentormentees, regularly. My advice:â–¶ï¸ Split marketing into three pillars: Strategy, Production (writing content, building landing pages, launching digital campaigns), Operations (arranging events, submitting award proposals, setting up CRM workflows).â–¶ï¸ Your Marketing leader should be doing all three. While significant time is spent on strategy, leadership should produce and run some operations to maintain perspective.â–¶ï¸ Experts handle the bulk of production. These can be in-house FTEs, agencies, freelancers or even AI agents, but the goal is top quality driven by deep experience.â–¶ï¸ Operations is where interns and recent graduates can shine because mindset and execution, rather than hard-skills and knowledge, are the success factors. Exposure to domain experts and real-world scenarios accelerates the transition from academia to a career.The above should help fresh faces into the marketing workforce, upskill rapidly through exposure, and benefit from their creative thinking.It might not be as efficient over the short term as â€œAI everythingâ€, but Iâ€™d letKlarnaCEOSebastian Siemiatkowski's recentBloomberginterview end with a note on cost vs. quality:Siemiatkowski said that [an all-in on AI for customer support] strategy isnâ€™t the right fit any more. â€œAs cost unfortunately seems to have been a too predominant evaluation factor when organizing this, what you end up having is lower quality,â€ he said. â€œReally investing in the quality of the human support is the way of the future for us.â€How do we blend quality, cost-efficiency, and social obligation to the next generation of talent together?
